docs.abstract: China’s foreign minister issues a stern warning that “the outcome will only be harmful” if the U.S. imposes more tariffs.
docs.snippet: China’s foreign minister issues a stern warning that “the outcome will only be harmful” if the U.S. imposes more tariffs.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China pledged Thursday to hit back at the United States if it sets off a trade war, issuing its strongest threat yet as President Trump prepares to impose more tariffs against China.

headline.main: China Vows Retaliation if Trump Engages in Trade War
headline.print_headline: China Vows Retaliation If U.S. Starts Trade War

docs.abstract: The justification for Washington’s tariffs on $60 billion in Chinese imports shows the rise of intellectual property as a major trade issue.
docs.snippet: The justification for Washington’s tariffs on $60 billion in Chinese imports shows the rise of intellectual property as a major trade issue.
docs.lead_paragraph: Arranged marriages. Whispered warnings. Outright theft.

headline.main: Beg, Borrow or Steal: How Trump Says China Takes Technology
headline.print_headline: How President Says Technology Is Taken

docs.abstract: They exploit our data and make us unhappy. They spread misinformation and undermine democracy. Is salvation possible for social networks?
docs.snippet: They exploit our data and make us unhappy. They spread misinformation and undermine democracy. Is salvation possible for social networks?
docs.lead_paragraph: I don’t need to tell you that something is wrong with social media.

headline.print_headline: Its Ideals Tainted, Can Social Media Shine Again?

docs.abstract: The country’s mild new prosperity has rekindled an interest in the 1980s, when the Japanese economy truly boomed and a sense of ascendance fueled spenders.
docs.snippet: The country’s mild new prosperity has rekindled an interest in the 1980s, when the Japanese economy truly boomed and a sense of ascendance fueled spenders.
docs.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Kaori Masukodera remembers, barely, riding as a child with her mother, her hair teased and her lips bright red, in the family’s convertible to the beach. It was the last gasp of the 1980s, a time of Champagne, garish colors and bubbly disco dance-floor anthems, and the last time many people in Japan felt rich and ascendant.

headline.main: Bright Lights, Big Shoulder Pads: A Timid Japan Recalls Its Bubble Era

docs.abstract: Liu He, long seen as a leader in Beijing’s effort to cure the country’s debt addiction, has been given unprecedented sway over its financial levers.
docs.snippet: Liu He, long seen as a leader in Beijing’s effort to cure the country’s debt addiction, has been given unprecedented sway over its financial levers.
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s president, Xi Jinping, has handed the reins of the country’s financial system to a close ally, strengthening his hold over the world’s second-largest economy and sending a clear signal that companies must reduce risky borrowing.

headline.main: Xi Taps Harvard-Educated Adviser to Tighten Grip on China’s Economy
headline.print_headline: China’s Leader Picks Harvard-Trained Ally to Tighten Grip on Economy

docs.abstract: Major products like Boeing planes and American soybeans may be singled out if Washington imposes new restrictions on China.
docs.snippet: Major products like Boeing planes and American soybeans may be singled out if Washington imposes new restrictions on China.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese officials have warned that they will retaliate against American companies if President Trump imposes tariffs on China, an American business group said on Tuesday, with airplanes and agricultural products among the likely targets.

headline.main: China Could Target U.S. Firms if Trump Levies Tariffs, Group Warns
headline.print_headline: Business Group Warns of Retaliation if Trump Hits China With Tariffs

docs.abstract: Artificial intelligence is here, and its effects are being felt across how we work. The New York Times examines the impact at its New Work Summit on Feb. 12 and 13.
docs.snippet: Artificial intelligence is here, and its effects are being felt across how we work. The New York Times examines the impact at its New Work Summit on Feb. 12 and 13.
docs.lead_paragraph: In Phoenix, cars are self-navigating the streets. In many homes, people are barking commands at tiny machines, with the machines responding. On our smartphones, apps can now recognize faces in photos and translate from one language to another.

headline.main: How Artificial Intelligence Is Edging Its Way Into Our Lives

docs.abstract: Apple gave us the modern smartphone. Now, it can create a new take on the device by encouraging us to use it more deliberately — and a lot less.
docs.snippet: Apple gave us the modern smartphone. Now, it can create a new take on the device by encouraging us to use it more deliberately — and a lot less.
docs.lead_paragraph: It’s not Apple’s fault that you feel enslaved by your phone. But the company that gave the world the modern smartphone has a perfect opportunity this year to create a brave and groundbreaking new take on that device: a phone that encourages you to use it more thoughtfully, more deliberately — and a lot less.

headline.main: It’s Time for Apple to Build a Less Addictive iPhone
headline.print_headline: It’s Time for a Lot Less iPhone

docs.abstract: Instead of revealing unseen order and predictability in the world, technology has made the world more volatile.
docs.snippet: Instead of revealing unseen order and predictability in the world, technology has made the world more volatile.
docs.lead_paragraph: Happy new year to you and yours, of course, but I’m going to have to put a halt to the festivities and play Frowning Farhad for a minute: You’re fooling yourself if you think 2018 is going to be any different, sanity- or anxiety-wise, from the roller coaster of the year just concluded.

headline.main: Expect 2018 to Be More Sane? Sorry, It’s Not Going to Happen
headline.print_headline: In 2018, Expect Chaos To Be the New Normal

docs.abstract: Carrol Amrich was already buckled into her seat when the online agency that had sold her ticket canceled it. Her mother died before she could say goodbye.
docs.snippet: Carrol Amrich was already buckled into her seat when the online agency that had sold her ticket canceled it. Her mother died before she could say goodbye.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a hospital in Minnesota, Carrol Amrich’s mother was dying.

headline.main: She Boarded a Plane to See Her Dying Mother. Then Her Ticket Was Canceled.
headline.print_headline: She Boarded a Plane to See Her Dying Mother. Then Her Ticket Was Canceled.
